svcsubproc.title: Output Shaft and Rear Bearing Assemblies

step1.para: Secure the output shaft in a vise with the threaded end up ( Figure 292). Install the stepped washer on the shaft, flat side down.

figure.caption: Figure 291. Secure Output Shaft in Vise

step1.para: Install the splined spacer and output shaft against washer, shoulder up ( Figure 293).

figure.caption: Figure 292. Install Splined Spacer and Output Shaft Against Washer

para.emph: IMPORTANT: For timing purposes, mark any two adjacent teeth on splitter gear and repeat the procedure for the two adjacent teeth directly opposite the first set marked ( Figure 294). A highly visible color of toolmaker's dye is recommended.

figure.caption: Figure 293. Mark Teeth on Splitter Gear For Timing Purposes

step1.para: If previously removed, install the snap ring in the splitter gear ( inset, Figure 2955). Install the gear on the output shaft, snap ring up and clutching teeth engaged with the splines of the spacer.

figure.caption: Figure 294. Install Snap Ring in Splitter Gear

step1.para: Install the stepped washer on the shaft against the gear, flat side up ( Figure 296).

figure.caption: Figure 295. Install Stepped Washer on Shaft Against Gear

step1.para: Heat the front bearing cone and install on output shaft against washer, bearing taper up ( Figure 297).

figure.caption: Figure 296. Heat Front Bearing Cone and Install

note.para: Do not heat bearing above 275 degrees F (136 degrees C). If possible, use heat lamps as source.

step1.para: Install the bearing inner spacer on the output shaft ( Figure 298).

figure.caption: Figure 297. Install Bearing Inner Spacer on Output Shaft

step1.para: Place the front bearing cup in the housing bore, taper to the inside ( Figure 299) and use a soft bar to start cup into the bore.

figure.caption: Figure 298. Place Front Bearing Cup in Housing Bore

step1.para: Stack the bearing outer spacer and rear bearing cup on top of the front bearing cup in proper sequence ( Figure 300). Use a flanged-end driver to move all three parts evenly into the bore until lip of rear bearing cup seats on the housing.

figure.caption: Figure 299. Stack Bearing Outer Spacer and Rear Bearing Cup on Top of Front Bearing Cup

step1.para: Install the auxiliary housing over the end of the output shaft assembly, seating the front bearing cone on the shaft in the cup ( Figure 301).

figure.caption: Figure 300. Install Auxiliary Housing Over End of Output Shaft Assembly

step1.para: Heat the rear bearing cone and install on the shaft, taper down and inside cup. Make sure the lip of the rear bearing cup is fully seated on the housing with the bearing installed ( Figure 302).

figure.caption: Figure 301. Heat Rear Bearing Cone and Install

note.para: Do not heat bearing above 275 degrees F (136 degrees C).

step1.para: If previously removed, install the oil seal in the rear bearing cover ( inset, igure 303). Seal should be installed so the spring is to the front of the cover.

figure.caption: Figure 302. Install Oil Seal in Rear Bearing Cover With Spring to Front of Cover

step1.para: Position the new gasket on the cover mounting surface and install the rear bearing cover on the auxiliary housing ( Figure 304). Use the nylon collar and brass washer with bolt at the chamfered hole which intersects speedometer bore ( inset, Figure 304). Apply Loctite 242 and tighten to 35 to 45 ft-lbs. (47 to 61 Nm).

figure.caption: Figure 303. Install Rear Bearing Cover and Use Nylon Collar and Brass Washer

note.para: Because the collar becomes distorted when compressed, DO NOT REUSE OLD NYLON COLLAR.
